stance_1: I appreciate the nutritional benefits of meat
stance_2: I like the taste of meat
justification: Enjoying the taste of meat and appreciating its nutritional benefits both support choosing to eat meat, even if not frequently.

stance_1: I appreciate the nutritional benefits of meat
stance_2: I eat meat two or three times some weeks
justification: Interviewee explicitly cites nutrition as a reason for eating meat, supporting the behavior of eating meat some weeks.

stance_1: I appreciate the nutritional benefits of meat
stance_2: I skip meat when I want to eat lighter
justification: Appreciating nutrition supports eating meat, but choosing to skip meat for lighter meals may conflict with nutritional motivations.

stance_1: I appreciate the nutritional benefits of meat
stance_2: I skip meat when I am not craving it
justification: Nutritional benefits promote eating meat, whereas skipping meat due to lack of craving can conflict with this motivation.

stance_1: I avoid meat when it requires a lot of prep
stance_2: Meat is sometimes too expensive for me
justification: Both cost and preparation effort are cited as reasons to avoid meat, showing supportive relationship between these practical barriers.

stance_1: I eat meat more during holidays or special meals
stance_2: I eat meat two or three times some weeks
justification: Eating meat on special occasions or a few times a week both indicate a moderate, non-daily pattern of meat consumption.

stance_1: I eat meat two or three times some weeks
stance_2: I skip meat when I want to eat lighter
justification: Eating meat some weeks is in tension with skipping meat to eat lighter, reflecting alternating motivations.

stance_1: I eat meat two or three times some weeks
stance_2: I skip meat when I am not craving it
justification: Eating meat some weeks is reduced when not craving it, showing a conflict between routine and preference.

stance_1: I eat meat two or three times some weeks
stance_2: Meat is sometimes too expensive for me
justification: Frequency of meat eating is reduced when meat is too expensive, indicating conflict between desire and budget.

stance_1: I eat meat two or three times some weeks
stance_2: I avoid meat when it requires a lot of prep
justification: The desire to eat meat some weeks is reduced by prep effort, showing a conflict between intention and convenience.

stance_1: I eat meat two or three times some weeks

justification: Interviewee and family share similar moderate, mood-driven meat-eating patterns.

stance_1: I eat meat two or three times some weeks
stance_2: My family skips meat for lighter meals
justification: Both the interviewee and family skip meat for lighter meals, indicating shared motivations.

stance_1: I like the taste of meat
stance_2: I eat meat two or three times some weeks
justification: Liking the taste supports eating meat on some weeks.

stance_1: I like the taste of meat
stance_2: I eat meat more during holidays or special meals
justification: Enjoyment of taste likely contributes to eating meat at special occasions.

stance_1: I like the taste of meat
stance_2: I skip meat when I am not craving it
justification: Craving and taste are closely linked; skipping meat when not craving it conflicts with liking its taste.

stance_1: I skip meat when I want to eat lighter
stance_2: I skip meat when I am not craving it
justification: Both are reasons to skip meat, reinforcing the behavior.

stance_1: I skip meat when I want to eat lighter
stance_2: My family skips meat for lighter meals
justification: Both the interviewee and family skip meat for lighter meals, showing a shared supportive pattern.

stance_1: I skip meat when I am not craving it

justification: Both skip meat under similar circumstances, showing support.

stance_2: I avoid meat when it requires a lot of prep

stance_1: My family eats meat when in the mood

stance_1: Some friends are vegan or vegetarian
stance_2: My friends are focused on health or the environment
justification: The vegan/vegetarian friends' focus on health/environment is explicitly stated as their motivation.
